channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Fighting Intensifies in Northeast as Russia Presses on Kupiansk
item.description: The area around Kupiansk, in northeastern Ukraine, is the only part of the front line where Russia is making noticeable gains.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: As Dolphins Die in Black Sea, Ukraine Builds Case for Ecocide Against Russia
item.description: The animals are dying in droves in the Black Sea, and Ukrainian officials are documenting the deaths, hoping to prosecute Russia for the war’s ecological toll.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preparing to perform a necropsy on a dolphin, under the supervision of the zoologist Pawel Goldin, left, in Odesa, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: How Ecuador’s Neighbors Unleashed Drug Violence on Its Soil
item.description: A presidential candidate’s assassination has focused global attention on the country’s extraordinary bloodshed fueled by powerful international and domestic crime groups.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and José María León Cabrera
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers arresting a man in May in the Guayaquil suburb of Durán, Ecuador. During the arrest, his mother, Ana, insisted her son was a drug user, not a dealer.

item.title: Canada Wildfire Forces Citywide Evacuation of Yellowknife
item.description: Officials told residents to clear out of the Northwest Territories city of Yellowknife by Friday afternoon. Most were expected to flee south by road.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Cars leaving Yellowknife on Wednesday after approaching wildfires prompted an evacuation order in the Canadian city.

item.title: Renewed Violence in Libya Reflects Power of Militias
item.description: Violence erupted this week in Libya’s capital, Tripoli, again sowing chaos in a country plagued by instability since the ouster of the dictator Muammar el-Qaddafi more than a decade ago.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Russell Goldman
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: Smoke billowing after clashes in Tripoli, Libya, on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden’s Camp David Summit Pulls Japan and South Korea Closer Amid China Challenges
item.description: The president will host the leaders of the two Asian democracies at Camp David, as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine spurs them to rapidly mend relations.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: President Biden, Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan and President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea during the Group of 7 summit in Hiroshima in May.

item.title: Women’s Right Activists in Iran Are Detained as Protests Anniversary Nears
item.description: They stand accused of planning to incite “chaos and vandalism” nearly a year after a young woman’s death in Iranian police custody sparked a mass rebellion.
item.dc:creator: Leily Nikounazar and Aaron Boxerman
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Thousands of protesters traveling last year to the cemetery in western Iran where Mahsa Amini, who died in police custody, was buried.

item.title: Hillsong Founder Acquitted of Hiding Sexual Abuse Committed by His Father
item.description: Brian Houston, who once led Hillsong, was charged because he did not inform the police after his father admitted in 1999 to sexually assaulting a young boy decades before.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Brian Houston, the former leader of the global megachurch Hillsong, outside court in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday.

item.title: More Than 60 Feared Dead After Boat Accident Off Cape Verde
item.description: The vessel carrying mostly Senegalese nationals was found off the coast of the West African archipelago. Thirty-eight people survived.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: A boat that departed Senegal with more than 100 migrants in early July capsized, and dozens of passengers are feared dead.

item.title: In France, Some Public Pools Are Victims of Budget Woes
item.description: As temperatures rise, a vast but aging system is feeling the strains of rising energy costs, increasing water scarcity and mounting pressure on public budgets.
item.dc:creator: Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle
item.media:description: Swimming at a pool in Lyon, France, last summer. As heat waves become more frequent in France, conflicts over spending priorities could become more common.

item.title: Germany Takes Step Toward Legalizing Marijuana
item.description: The government signed off on legislation that would allow adults to buy and possess small amounts of cannabis. Parliament still needs to approve the measure.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Supporters of marijuana legalization at a parade in Berlin on Saturday.

item.title: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s California Vacation
item.description: Thanks in part to careful media handling, the British prime minister, who has been criticized for his wife’s wealth and his U.S. ties, survived a trip to California with barely a peep of reproach.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain and his wife, Akshata Murty, with their daughters, Krishna, far left, and Anoushka in Santa Monica, Calif, this month.

item.title: Sweden Raises Terrorism Threat Amid Quran Burnings: What to Know
item.description: The country has found itself caught between outrage over anti-Muslim actions and its commitment to free speech. Denmark has also wrestled with the same tensions.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Iraqi police officers trying to disperse a protest outside the Swedish Embassy in Baghdad in July.

item.title: Bank of Ireland Glitch Creates Brief Illusion of Free Money
item.description: Some A.T.M.s around the country attracted long lines — and a police presence — after customers were apparently allowed to transfer money they did not have.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A “technical issue” with Bank of Ireland’s online banking services allowed some customers to move money without affecting their account balances, the bank said.

item.title: Private Jet Crashes Into Malaysia Highway, Killing 10
item.description: The plane crashed on the outskirts of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia’s capital and largest city, killing all eight people on board and two people on the ground.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: A light plane crashed on a street in Malaysia’s central Selangor state on Thursday, killing eight people on board and two motorists.

item.title: In China, More Single Female Home Buyers, Resisting Sexist Norms
item.description: The housing market in China is in turmoil. But more and more women, facing a less equal society, are buying their own homes in search of security.
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The residential compound in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou where Guo Miaomiao bought an apartment.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: A deadly boat accident off Cape Verde.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A beach in Fass Boye, Senegal.

item.title: Allies to Be Allowed to Send F-16s to Ukraine, U.S. Official Says
item.description: The jets can be sent once Ukrainian pilots are trained to operate them.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, John Ismay and Lauren McCarthy
item.media:credit: Henning Bagger/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Danish F-16 fighter jets performing at an airshow in Denmark last year.

item.title: Frontline Villages in Southern Ukraine Endure Shelling Day and Night
item.description: Small villages along a buffer area between Ukrainian and Russian positions on the Zaporizhzhia front have come under increasingly heavy bombardment.
item.dc:creator: Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alla Viktorivna, center, a seller at a street market in Stepnohirsk, Ukraine, last week.

item.title: Friday Briefing: The U.S. Pulls Japan and South Korea Closer
item.description: Also, questions about new weight loss drugs.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: President Biden, Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan and President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea during the Group of 7 summit in Japan in May.

item.title: North Koreans Are Starved and Forced to Work, U.N. Hears
item.description: At a Security Council meeting, officials gave harrowing accounts of rights abuses in North Korea. But global divisions were clear: Russia denounced the discussion, and China questioned its validity.
item.dc:creator: Amanda E. Newman
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Volker Türk, the U.N. high commissioner for human rights, speaking to the Security Council on Thursday. Rarely had North Korea “been more painfully closed to the outside world than it is today,” he said.

item.title: Pilot Dies After Medical Emergency on Flight From Miami to Chile
item.description: The pilot, part of a three-member crew, died after the Latam Airlines flight made an emergency landing in Panama on Monday, the airline said.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:description: The plane, a Boeing 787, was forced to make a diversion to Panama because of the pilot’s “medical emergency,” Latam Airlines said in a statement on Thursday.

item.title: Ancient Fires Drove Sabertooth Cats and Other Large Mammals Extinct, Study Suggests
item.description: Fossils from La Brea Tar Pits in Southern California suggest that sabertooth cats and other large North American mammals disappeared as a result of wildfires spurred by human activity.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller

item.title: White House Targets Key Democrats on Potential Saudi-Israel Pact
item.description: The White House needs to persuade two historic adversaries to find common ground. But then the administration faces a potentially more daunting challenge: getting 67 senators to go along with it.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Mark Mazzetti
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Any new treaty with Saudi Arabia would require support from two-thirds of the Senate.

item.title: 4 Australians Are Rescued After 36 Hours on Surfboards at Sea
item.description: The Australians and two members of their boat’s Indonesian crew were found after an extensive search off the coast of North Sumatra, Indonesia. A third crew member is still missing.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: BARARNAS, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo provided by the National Search and Rescue Agency in Indonesia shows some of the Australian surfers who were found bobbing on surfboards after 36 hours at sea.

item.title: NATO Chief Clarifies Stance on Possible Ukraine Membership
item.description: Officials on both sides of the conflict balked at the suggestion that Ukraine should cede territory in order to join the alliance.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Tor Erik Schroder/NTB, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Jens Stoltenberg, NATO’s secretary general, was forced to clarify the alliance’s stance on Ukraine’s possible membership on Thursday.

item.title: Aleksandar Matanovic, Whose Publishing Company Changed Chess, Dies at 93
item.description: Largely self-taught, he became a grandmaster in his 20s and was later a founder of Chess Informant, which revolutionized how people studied the game.
item.dc:creator: Dylan Loeb McClain

item.title: Israel’s $3.5 Billion Defense Deal With Germany Gets U.S. Approval
item.description: Israel said that the U.S. government had approved its request to sell Germany a missile defense system, setting in motion a $3.5 billion agreement that Israeli officials described as the country’s “largest ever” weapons deal.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: An Arrow 3 missile during a test launch in Israel in 2015. The Arrow 3 missile defense system is designed to intercept ballistic missiles outside the earth’s atmosphere.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Will Not Receive F-16 Jets From NATO Allies This Year
item.description: A spokesman for the Ukrainian Air Force said the advanced planes wouldn’t arrive by winter, meaning they won’t play a role in the latest counteroffensive push.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: A Romanian Air Force F-16 fighter jet during a media day in July.

item.title: How to Survive in the Heat: Coping Advice From Around the World
item.description: And other time-tested ways to cope with extreme heat from cultures around the world.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Threats to counterterrorism efforts from the coup in Niger.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Niger has been a centerpiece of American efforts to combat Islamist militants in the region.

item.title: Ukraine Recaptures a Small Village as Russian Forces Retreat
item.description: The announcement came on the same day that a cargo ship stranded in the Odesa port became the first to venture into the turbulent waters of the Black Sea despite Moscow’s threats to treat vessels in the area as hostile.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier last month in the village of Blagodatne, near Urozhaine, in the Donetsk region. Ukraine announced the recapture of Urozhaine on Wednesday.

item.title: Coup in Niger Upends U.S. Terrorism Fight and Could Open a Door for Russia
item.description: The military takeover could force the Pentagon to withdraw 1,100 American troops and close drone bases in the West African country.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Declan Walsh and Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Supporters of the military coup celebrating in Niamey, Niger, in July. The impoverished nation has in recent years slowed a wave of extremists pushing south to coastal states.

item.title: Hurricane Hilary Is Now Category 3; Storm Will Bring Rain to California
item.description: Torrential rain is expected to hit the Southwestern United States on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Judson Jones

item.title: Two American Tourists Caught Sleeping in the Eiffel Tower
item.description: The two men posed no threat and were handed over to the police, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: The Paris prosecutor’s office said that two American men had been found sleeping on the site of the Eiffel Tower and that alcohol was involved.

item.title: In Test of Ukraine’s New Black Sea Corridor, Cargo Ship Travels From Odesa
item.description: Kyiv is aiming to resume traffic to its seaports despite Russia’s threats to ships moving to and from Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A cargo ship is seen leaving the southern port of Odesa on Wednesday.

item.title: ‘Chitty Chitty Bang Bang’ Windmill Is for Sale in England
item.description: The property, which was the home of Dick Van Dyke’s character in the 1968 film, is listed for 9 million pounds, or $11.4 million.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Hughes Warfield/United Artists Britain, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The windmill survived this encounter with Van Dyke’s character’s latest invention.

item.title: Thai Court Dismisses Pita’s Renomination
item.description: Pita Limjaroenrat won a surprise victory in the general election, but his attempts to form a government and become the nation’s next premier have been thwarted.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times

item.title: Russian Drones Attack Ukrainian Ports on Danube River
item.description: Russian drones hit the ports of Reni and Izmail and damaged warehouses used to export grain, Ukrainian officials said.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: A handout image from the Ukrainian Armed Forces showed a damaged grain warehouse at a port on the Danube River in Ukraine’s Odesa region on Wednesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Donald Trump’s response to another criminal indictment.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump said “all charges should be dropped against me & others” as he announced a news conference he plans to host on Monday.

item.title: Amid Attacks, Ukraine’s Grain Exports Get a Lifeline From Romania
item.description: A 40-mile channel, best known outside shipping circles as a magnet for bird watchers, is now a crucial route allowing Ukrainian grain to reach the sea, protected by a NATO umbrella.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ship at the Romanian port of Sulina, the main gateway to ports in the Danube River delta, this month. The nearby Sulina Channel has kept grain flowing since Russia started attacking Ukrainian ports.

item.title: Tony Blair, Former U.K. Leader, Is Suddenly Back in Favor
item.description: The former British prime minister, who left Downing Street widely unpopular, is back in favor with his party, Labour, which hopes his political skills can be an advantage as an election nears.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Blair, Tony, Institute for Global Change
item.media:credit: Liam McBurney/Press Association, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Tony Blair ended his term as prime minister detested by many Britons, particularly on the left. Before that, however, he won three successive general elections.

item.title: North Korea Confirms Detention of Travis King, U.S. Soldier
item.description: The statement was the first public acknowledgment by the country that it has the soldier, Pvt. Travis King, in its custody.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A file image of a news program on the American soldier Travis King at the Seoul Railway Station in Seoul last month.

item.title: Russia’s Interest Rate Hike Highlights Economic Struggle Amid Ukraine War
item.description: With the third-largest interest rate increase in a decade to shore up the ruble, Moscow’s policymakers are pursuing the conflicting goals of paying for the war against Ukraine and taming inflation.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Red Square in Moscow last month.

item.title: Can Koyo Kouoh Revive Zeitz MOCAA?
item.description: “There was a feeling that we cannot let this fail,” Koyo Kouoh said of taking the top job at Zeitz MOCAA. She wants to make it relevant to the Pan-African world and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Roslyn Sulcas
item.category: Zeitz Museum of Contemporary Art Africa
item.media:credit: Tsele Nthane for The New York Times
item.media:description: Koyo Kouoh, the executive director of the Zeitz Museum of Contemporary Art Africa, in Cape Town, S.A., with Lynette Yiadom-Boakye’s canvas, “11 p.m. Friday.”

item.title: In Greece, a ‘Beach Towel Movement’ Fights for a Spot on the Sand
item.description: As lounge chairs that rent for up to $130 pop up across the islands, local people have decided they won’t take it lying down.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Protesters demonstrating to “reclaim the beach” in July at Marcello and Krios beach on the island of Paros, Greece.

item.title: U.K. Reveals 5 Espionage Arrests After BBC Reports Russia Link
item.description: Britain’s counterterrorism unit arrested the five on suspicion of spying on British intelligence, the authorities said following a BBC report that three of the same people had been accused of spying for Russia.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: The Metropolitan Police headquarters in London, formally called New Scotland Yard.

item.title: Families of 17 USS Cole Sailors Killed by Al Qaeda Await Justice at Guantánamo Bay
item.description: Families of the sailors who were killed in the bombing of the U.S.S. Cole and survivors having been making the trek to the war court at Guantánamo Bay for pretrial hearings since 2011.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Sean Rayford for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I can’t name another case in United States history, a criminal case, that has taken 20 years to prosecute,” said Anton J. Gunn, whose brother Cherone was killed in the bombing at age 22.

item.title: At Least 3 Dead After Russian Missile Attacks in Western Ukraine
item.description: Officials said more than three dozen missiles were fired in the strikes that were far from the front lines in the east and south.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Rescuers working at a site of a Russian military strike in Lviv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Typhoon Lan Brings Heavy Rain and Winds to Western Japan
item.description: The heavy rains and winds brought by the storm prompted evacuation warnings and the cancellation of hundreds of flights.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida
item.media:description: Heavy rain in Tanabe, Wakayama Prefecture, as Typhoon Lam hit, on Tuesday.

item.title: Dozens Said to Be Missing After Myanmar Jade Mine Landslide
item.description: The disaster occurred in Kachin State, where wildcat jade miners toil in dangerous conditions and landslides are common during the monsoon season.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Tarlin Mg/Ugc, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescue workers and onlookers at the site of the landslide in Kachin State in northern Myanmar on Sunday.

item.title: The Hidden Trauma of Ukraine’s Soldiers
item.description: Facing a growing mental health crisis among soldiers, Ukraine’s therapists and doctors use a variety of treatments, but the need far outstrips the available care.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: There is a crisis of wounded psyches, in addition to broken bodies, among Ukrainian soldiers.

item.title: The Ukrainian Mechanics Who Fix Tanks at the War’s Frontline
item.description: Behind the thousands of troops fighting the counteroffensive are engineers and technicians who perform an essential, and often dangerous, job.
item.dc:creator: Oleksandr Chubko and Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the 37th Marine Brigade repairing a vehicle near the front in southern Ukraine last month.

item.title: Xuxa Was Brazil’s Barbie. Now She’s Saying Sorry.
item.description: Xuxa was once Brazil’s biggest TV star. Now many are wondering whether a thin, blond, white woman was the right idol for such a diverse country.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:description: Xuxa on a television show on the network Globo in the 1980s. She says she now laments the beauty standards she portrayed.

item.title: Dozens Are Killed in Fire at Gas Station in Dagestan, Russia
item.description: Reports from news agencies said at least 35 people were killed and 66 hospitalized in Dagestan, but there were no immediate reports of foul play or of a connection to the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Emergency responders at the scene of the fire in Makhachkala, in the Dagestan region of Russia, on Monday night.

item.title: Russia Fires Warning Shots and Boards a Freighter in the Black Sea
item.description: Russia’s military made good on its threats to enforce its blockade of Ukraine, adding to the tensions in an increasingly active theater of war.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Jenny Gross and Christiaan Triebert
item.media:credit: Center for Strategic Communications, via Reuters
item.media:description: A video shared widely, including by Ukraine’s government, showing a Russian helicopter hovering over the ship Sukru Okan in the Black Sea on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. Ambassador Meets Evan Gershkovich, Detained WSJ Reporter, in Russia
item.description: American officials have said that their Russian counterparts are blocking them from getting regular consular access to Mr. Gershkovich.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: The U.S. ambassador to Russia, Lynne Tracy, after a hearing in Moscow in June to consider an appeal against the detention of Evan Gershkovich.

item.title: Latvia’s Prime Minister, Krisjanis Karins, Is to Resign
item.description: Krisjanis Karins had wanted to reshuffle his cabinet but was rebuffed by his governing coalition partners.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Krisjanis Karins of Latvia in Brussels last month. He said on Monday that the other parties in the coalition were “blocking work for welfare and economic growth.”

item.title: For Ukraine, Many Antiwar Activists in the U.S. Make an Exception
item.description: Several reasons might explain the differing response, including the fact that no American troops have been committed to the fight.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Ukraine demonstrating in Washington. Many activists who condemn war in general are supporting American efforts to defend Ukraine.
